clinical_study.brief_title: Early Functional Training in Acute Stroke Inpatient Ward
clinical_study.official_title: The Effect of Two Models of an Early Intervention Program on Functional Recovery at Three Months to Acute Stroke Patients: A Randomized Controlled Trial

brief_summary.textblock: To investigate the difference between two models of an early intervention program (focused on mobility function) in the functional recovery 3 months post stroke in a group of patients with acute ischemic stroke while in acute inpatient ward hospitalization.

detailed_description.textblock: Patients with acute stroke admit into an acute inpatient ward who meet study criteria and provide institutional-reviewed consent form will be randomly assigned into either model 1 or model 2 of an early functional training program. Participants in model 1 group will receive 2 sessions of functional training per day whereas those in model 2 group will receive 1 session of functional training and 1 session of friendly visit and education per day. The following outcomes will be measured at admission, at discharge and at 3 months post stroke: Barthel index (BI), Postural Assessment Scale for Stroke (PASS), Mobility Scale for Acute Stroke (MASA), and usual gait speed (UGS). The rater is blinded to participants' group membership.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- patient with acute ischemic stroke
- referred for early rehabilitation,
- aged 65 years or more,
- moderate stroke severity NIHSS=4~16
Exclusion Criteria:
- able to walk independently and safely at admission,
- hemi-neglect,
- unable to understand three simple comments,
- unable to recovery even with appropriate medical management,
- serious condition require ICU care,
- terminal illness for hospice care,
- waiting to transfer to long term care facilities
